children.information: Used to describe habits, unchanging situations, general truths, and fixed arrangements. The simple present tense is simple to form. Just use the base form of the verb
children.example: (I take, you take, we take, they take) The 3rd person singular takes an -s at the end. (he takes, she takes)

children.information: Used for actions happening now or for an action that is unfinished. This tense is also used when the action is temporary.
children.example: Aunt Christine is 'warming' up the car while Scott looks for his new leather coat.

children.information: Used to show that an action has taken place once or many times before now.The present perfect is formed using has/have + past participle.
Used to refer to an unspecified time between 'before now' and 'now'. . The present perfect continuous is formed using the construction has/have been + the present participle (root + -ing).
children.example: I 'have been reading' War and Peace for a month now.

children.information: The simple past is a verb tense that is used to talk about things that happened or existed before now.
The past continuous describes actions or events in a time before now, which began in the past and is still going on at the time of speaking.
children.example: They 'were waiting' for the bus when the accident happened.

children.information: The past perfect refers to a time earlier than before now. It is used to make it clear that one event happened before another in the past.
Used to refer to an unspecified time between 'before now' and 'now'. . The present perfect continuous is formed using the construction has/have been + the present participle (root + -ing).
children.example: Martha 'had been walking' three miles a day before she broke her leg..

children.information: The past perfect continuous tense is constructed using had been + the verb’s present participle (root + -ing).
children.example: Jen is <bold>not going to quit</bold> before she reaches her goal.

children.information: The simple future tense is a verb tense that is used when an action is expected to occur in the future and be completed.It is formed using the construction will + be + the present participle (the root verb + -ing).
children.example: I 'will be stressed' tomorrow during my science test.

children.information: The future perfect is a verb tense used for actions that will be completed before some other point in the future.
children.example: 'You will have finished' your report by this time next week.

children.information: The future perfect continuous, also sometimes called the future perfect progressive, is a verb tense that describes actions that will continue up until a point in the future. The future perfect continuous consists of will + have + been + the verb’s present participle (verb root + -ing).
children.example: She 'is going to have been working' at that company for three years when it finally closes.
